body:
> Please add a test.

Hi, I went through the testing guide but couldn't find an exact detail of how to add a test to the code, could you please point me to an example?

@therajdeepbiswas You should add a test to Get-Process.Tests.ps1 file. The test should be skipped if not `$IsLinux`. I guess we can not rename process on the fly so we have to create an executable file with appropriate name (like "T ( E ( S ) T)") and run it. Perhaps we could use https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11130229/start-a-process-with-a-name
Stack Overflow
Start a process with a name
Basically I want to dynamically start some processes which may create their own children processes, also I want to kill a certain group of processes I just created whenever I want. One way I could ...

> create an executable file with appropriate name (like "T ( E ( S ) T)") and run it.

@iSazonov I don't think it is possible to assign an alias with special characters from within PowerShell (so as to be executed from a testcase). ~If I were to do it from bash, that alias wouldn't carry over to PowerShell when I run the latter~. And even if I'm going to create a custom executable, that extra file will always be hardcoded for that one test case, isn't it?

I thought it would be better to create a temporary file for one manual test.
I called it "t(e(s)t)" and the contents of it are as follows
`#!/bin/bash`
`pwsh`

After executing this from bash, it launched PowerShell as expected and on running `Get-Process`, you can note that it was indeed listed in the process list as shown below in the screenshot.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32306614/84246488-53b89700-ab24-11ea-8d32-6b1d73be209f.png)

And indeed the issue seems to have been solved from the one manual test, as shown below.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32306614/84246586-75198300-ab24-11ea-9263-eafad9bf16f9.png)

I don't think including this one file to run testcases on it time and again makes any sense. So it will be unnecessary to include the hardcoded testcase, however, I have added a testcase that checks if the parent property returned is not not null when looked up using process name (and not process ID). Adding in next commit.

[![CLA assistant check](https://cla.opensource.microsoft.com/pull/badge/signed)](https://cla.opensource.microsoft.com/PowerShell/PowerShell?pullRequest=12925)
All CLA requirements met.
The CI test for macos is failing on a pester file I did not change anything in. Please suggest me how to fix this.
_Lmao_
@iSazonov what now?

@therajdeepbiswas Please fix the test and make the test positive to cover the new code path.
> Your test never checks the new code path on Linux. If we remove the cs code the test will pass.

> @therajdeepbiswas Please fix the test and make the test positive to cover the new code path.

@iSazonov My test file, in itself is working when executed offline using `Start-PSPester -Path test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Management/Get-Process.Tests.ps1`, and the new testcase which I wrote seems to be passing as can be inferred from the screenshot below.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32306614/84269313-aefb8100-ab46-11ea-9d98-7156cb88bccc.png)


> The CI test for macos is failing on a pester file I did not change anything in.

and, as I mentioned earlier, the build was failing on a test file I hadn't modified at all.
The following results are from the automated tests
`Check failure on line 1 in Test-Connection.Error occurred in Describe block`
`azure-pipelines / PowerShell-CI-macos`
`Test-Connection.Error occurred in Describe block`
`Exception calling "GetHostEntry" with "1" argument(s): "nodename nor servname provided, or not known"`
Raw Output: `At /Users/runner/runners/2.169.1/work/1/s/test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Management/Test-Connection.Tests.ps1:15 char:9`

Please note that `Test-Connection.Tests.ps1` is a file I did not modify.

> and make the test positive to cover the new code path.

PS: also, I'm not sure what you mean by 'cover the new code path', could you please care to elaborate?

> the build was failing on a test file I hadn't modified at all.

It is because there is a bug in .Net. (Process name is "ConsoleHost mai".) After the bug will be fixed your test will pass. You should create a process name so that your new code is executed in the new test.

> create a process name

By this do you mean a test that invokes the Get-Process function which I modified?
Yes. You could use Bash sample you mentioned above.
That can only be done through a manual test, right? How can you write a pester test that executes a custom bash file?

You can create a bash script file on fly, set exec flag by chmod +x and run the script from pwsh.
```
PS /home/sie> & './t t.sh'

 NPM(K)    PM(M)      WS(M)     CPU(s)      Id  SI ProcessName
 ------    -----      -----     ------      --  -- -----------
      0     0.00       4.97       0.40       8   8 bash
      0     0.00      99.42       1.51    2412   8 ConsoleHost mai
      0     0.00      85.93       0.70    2440   8 ConsoleHost mai
      0     0.00       0.54       0.02       1   0 init
      0     0.00       0.08       0.00       6   6 init
      0     0.00       0.08       0.39       7   6 init
      0     0.00       3.11       0.00    2439   8 t t.sh

```
@iSazonov please check if this is what you are talking about.
@iSazonov Done as you suggested. Please check.
@therajdeepbiswas Please have a look at the failures.

Hi @adityapatwardhan 
I think the macos fails are being caused due to how @iSazonov describe the .net bug.
> > the build was failing on a test file I hadn't modified at all.
> 
> It is because there is a bug in .Net. (Process name is "ConsoleHost mai".) After the bug will be fixed your test will pass. You should create a process name so that your new code is executed in the new test.

And about the linux fails, I think they're because of an unbuilt version of pwsh. (The pwsh in the current branch is still running the version that is not bug free, right?)
The workaround with bash doesn't seems work for C# app. We could create a host application for the test but I think it's not worth  for the edge case.

@therajdeepbiswas I think current test could be removed.

Perhaps @adityapatwardhan has an idea about adding test or agree to merge without test.

> @therajdeepbiswas I think current test could be removed.
> 
> Perhaps @adityapatwardhan has an idea about adding test or agree to merge without test. 

Waiting on confirmation about this, @iSazonov
